Paracetamol has not been very effective for this covid fever so last night I put a cold compress over my face like a Victorian novel heroine dying of the consumption. My body may be broken but my theatrics are in tip top condition.

@Anna__mb @WikiDocJames Technically neither are true. Covid is mild for some and not for others. It's unpredictable by its nature and that's why we need to exercise some caution. One person's experience (whether your own or not) isn't the true picture of the virus.

@Anna__mb @WikiDocJames Of course it's changed as a result of immunity but your first tweet quite literally reads COVID IS MILD. Those are the words you typed. It's not correct in a lot of situations, and there's still quite a few people dying. It's a mild illness for many, but still unpredictable.

@Anna__mb @WikiDocJames By your own logic because you, a person who hasn't been vaxxed, doesn't get symptoms does not mean it's a mild disease for everyone who gets it. Deaths have dropped dramatically since vaccines, and the evidence to suggest they've made a positive difference is overwhelming.
@grownupgapyear Oh 10 days is ages to wait! Yeah I don't feel great tbh. The body aches are the worst part so far. And not being able to stay one temperature 🤣
@grownupgapyear Glad you're revovering. Can I ask how long it took to test negative? I'm hoping I can go to a hen do next weekend but looking questionable! That line is pretty hostile. 🤣

@DarceyButtell @spawnofthediva_ @Tweet_Dec I'm also likely to inherit my parents' London flat at some point in my life. They don't rent it now- it's used by them for trips to London & their friends and family. But in all likelihood in the future I would probably end up renting it.

@DarceyButtell @spawnofthediva_ @Tweet_Dec Are dealt with immediately. Probably good to build trust with tenants too so they feel they can come to you in a crisis. With a long-term let I wouldn't care about wall painting, pictures etc. Though I might ask for a repaint after they leave if it was bright purple (for example)

@DarceyButtell @spawnofthediva_ @Tweet_Dec I will likely be a landlord at some point- or at least do holiday rentals. This is because my partner and I don't want children & would rather buy 2 smaller places in different locations than a family home. My plan would be to rent out just under market rent & ensure any issues

@clareswatman @JournalistJill It's not that I don't want to eat these lovely things. The calorie counts just help me be clever about it 🤣 I am very small so I only need 1700 day really. Makes me choosy!

Are you in couples therapy in a relatively new relationship? (Under a year). I'd love to speak to women aged under 35 who are currently in this situation and would be willing to talk about it for a sensitive feature in a women's publication. @Victoria_Spratt #journorequest
@clareswatman @JournalistJill I never knew croissants were sometimes 700 calories. They're absolutely not worth it. 🤣

@clareswatman @JournalistJill Many people bother to look. I'm always shocked by how many cals can be in a packaged sandwich or takeaway drink for example. Seems so much more than the same thing at home.

@clareswatman @JournalistJill It's more that I have no idea what's in it. I don't really count calories at home but I can take a good guess. I think hidden calories are one of the reasons for the obesity epidemic. We just don't know what we are eating with processed food. To be fair though, I don't know if
@clareswatman @JournalistJill I think having calorie counts just helps me eat in a more mindful way and think about my choices a little more. (I'll always just order if I really want it though.)

@clareswatman @JournalistJill I quite like the idea tbh. It's not going to stop me eating something I really want but will help me avoid the sneaky calories when I'm out. That's what bugs me- when something very basic somehow has zillions of calories? Feels like a waste to eat it and now I can avoid.

@fliceverett No. I always make pies with leftover roast chicken (even if it's a couple of days old) then I often reheat it again. You get food poisoning by not cooking it properly and then not heating it properly once it's cooled- especially if it's been out on the side.
@fliceverett That's the dream now, but even more so at 70.

@flamingnora Mine was boiled potatoes, smashed on a plate with a bit of leftover ham and some cheese I melted in a pan to make "raclette" only it was cheddar and random Spanish cheese which formed a hard lump within three seconds of coming off the heat. Cheese is cheese though so all good.

@nlgreen @Heidivel Once you're an adult you should have been exposed to the germs you need for immune system 'coverage'. If anything you'd get less sick after lockdowns as we are doing more handwashing. But kids make a huge difference as you're more exposed to new germs.
@FilmFan1971 Such poor form on the testing too as they're meant to record incidents of food poisoning on public health grounds. I hope you make a full recovery soon!

@FilmFan1971 That's annoying they wouldn't test you as norovirus (and sometimes covid) can bring on the exact same symptoms. Apparently sudden onset vomiting is common with this new variant but nobody seems to know? Complain to Tesco anyway though!
@FilmFan1971 Glad you're recovering! Could the covid have caused the sickness or did they confirm food poisoning? If you got a pathogen report you can get some money for sure!
@juliasreading @RoseStokes There's usually one of these posts that gets trotted out once every couple of months. I think it's a push on right wing, American family values and religion.

@nickylep @YvonneBurdett3 @Liz_Wheeler Also research shows that around one in 12 people regrets having kids, so there's that to think about too. It's not for everyone. If people want to do it, great but don't try to tell others what to do.

@nickylep @YvonneBurdett3 @Liz_Wheeler You could say that about most choices. You don't know until you've tried & you don't get to try everything in the world because life isn't long enough. You make an informed decision based on the evidence you have. For me that means no children, for others it might mean 3 or 4.

@Amezyarak Ha ha yes. Because some people are really into it and want that in a match. I wouldn't want to match with someone and then later feel I wasn't able to offer them what they needed. (Especially if we got on well.) It means you'll cut out all the ppl who wouldn't be right anyway.

@Amezyarak I'd say more about yourself with a line at the end saying. In the interest of honesty I should say I'm not cut out for a vanilla life, but I promise I'm not a pervert! It is important to mention though I think. (From a vanilla girl.)

@johnlevenstein @jamiattenberg Or they don't get up much? I like the aisle because I have to pee all the time (TMI) but also I am just fidgety in general. All the window seat people I've  been next to are like statues with one pee break in a nine hour flight.

@EimearFreelance @KatStorrWriter I agree having young kids made it uniquely exhausting for people. I was bored at times but in a way I preferred it to some of the other periods where the rules were confusing and wishwashy. I knew where I stood and everyone was in the same boat (or storm).

@EimearFreelance @KatStorrWriter Everyone kept asking me if I was ok in the first lockdown because I was completely alone. But I don't care what anyone says about the struggles of single people, never let them tell you it was harder than having under 5s and a full-time job. It just can't possibly be true.

@matthewmole @premnsikka I do this. I switched from sole trader due to demand from clients. To be clear you also pay corporation tax so your take home pay is very similar- it's slightly less tax than paid in a full-time job but you get no benefits or security.

@mk_dodge @premnsikka It's from the IFS. In 2019 they recorded a 10 percentage point increase over the past decade in people not paying. That includes pensioners. @mippy @WillLloydDav @agw1437 @CharlotteCGill Ah ok. Yeah I can't trade up (in the same area) but I still call it a ladder just as anything you own is technically on it. I don't necessarily think of it as something to climb up though.

@mippy @WillLloydDav @agw1437 @CharlotteCGill It's possible in a flat, just not mine. Flats can be large enough for a family but not when they're less than 40 square metres and only have one bedroom. There wouldn't be room for a child's bed in my home.

@mippy @WillLloydDav @agw1437 @CharlotteCGill Wouldn't getting on the housing ladder, even if you didn't move up, provide a secure home? Or are you referring to more secure renting options and never buying?

@mippy @WillLloydDav @agw1437 @CharlotteCGill The ladder is really just family related/moving in with partners I think. I don't have kids so my flat is still doable but it wouldn't be possible to have a family here. I'd have to move out of London if I wanted children.

@WillLloydDav @mippy @agw1437 @CharlotteCGill It may drop a bit this year... But possibly not enough to get people on the ladder. I have hugely compromised on space to get my place. It's barely 40 square metres... I do love it but I would like a second bedroom, room for a bit more furniture at some point. Not possible!

@WillLloydDav @mippy @agw1437 @CharlotteCGill I just don't like them to look at. I think my flat might be ex-council too but it's a period property. @johnnystraycat @Spencer_Berg_ @RubinReport I don't want to take away anyone's right to be a surrogate. I'm simply suggesting we consider the ethics and regulations surrounding it, both altruistic and commercial. It can be a beautiful thing but it's often exploitative too.

@m_sherrill @johnnystraycat @Spencer_Berg_ @RubinReport But is it enough? I don't doubt it's better than other countries comparatively but there's still a lot of discussion around ethics. https://t.co/6MU6NU4xYJ
Dear park weirdos, it's not shorts weather. We are at least 10-20 degrees shy.

@Spencer_Berg_ @RubinReport Might not care about your surrogate, do you know how the experience was for her? Not all surrogacy is bad, but in the commercial sense it's very often wealthier people renting out the wombs of much poorer women who have very few good options for the long-term.

@Spencer_Berg_ @RubinReport It's not to do with two fathers having a child (that's lovely). And it's not to do with the child missing their mother. It's about women's rights. @JjhColin @little_emmabird Inside IR35, they often don't. Because I'm paying it. IR35 was introduced so that companies paid National Insurance for contract workers. @ElmlyRobbie Again you are conflating the tiny group of femcels with celibate women more generally. But this is a point that could be shared by a man too. Dating app culture hurts both sexes.

@ElmlyRobbie On due to space reasons which include attachment styles (for both men and women), family upbringing, the impact of online dating on communication styles etc.

@ElmlyRobbie The hook for the article was the online subculture of femcels. I've then broadened the topic out to look at the issues that make involuntary a much wider spread issue across all age groups. (That's where safety, misogyny etc come in.) There are of course other issues not touched

@ElmlyRobbie Yes, again you're converging two groups. There are online femcels who believe they're too ugly for sex & there are other women who are involuntarily celibate but don't identify as femcels. Many of them are attractive/successful women and this is who the therapist refers to here.

@ElmlyRobbie In the case of "true femcels" (in the first few paragraphs) they blame their issues on their looks. I then go on to talk about women who are celibate but don't define as femcel in online groups. They touch on issues of misogyny contributing to their challenges.
@ElmlyRobbie They would be criticising racism and in this sense, women are criticising misogyny. The only male behaviour being criticised by women in this feature is brought about by misogyny.

@ElmlyRobbie Wrong way around. It's would be hard to criticise the lived experience of Black people who say white people have behaved a certain way. It's true, because I've never lived it so can't judge their experiences. If they tell me they've been mistreated by white people I believe it
@ElmlyRobbie He argues that both are unacceptable, but that they don't come from the same place. If you stamp out misogyny, misandry would follow.

@ElmlyRobbie Misogyny exists as an ideology to prevent women from becoming equals. It's like when people are "racist" against white people. The vast maj of time it's not true racism, but instead a manifestation of distrust/anger against white people due to the way they've been treated.

@ElmlyRobbie What the therapist means is that while misandry can exist on its own, it's usually a reaction to misogynistic behaviour as opposed to a true hatred of men. For example, women might say "I'm scared of men, they can be violent or abusive" because that's their lived experience.

@chonkhonkmonk I don't believe there is one answer. Building self esteem, dismantling misogynistic attitudes, working on our collective communication skills (as a society) probably all play a role. Perhaps even attempting to build a less "couples centric" world where ppl would feel less lonely.

@rhiannonev Avoid dairy too- fat is much harder to digest and sits in the stomach for longer. It feels temporarily cooling to drink milk & eat yoghurt but the acid will be in your stomach trying to digest. Fresh fish (small portions) is very good too. Avoid tomatoes, OJ, chocolate etc...

@rhiannonev I have chronic reflux. Try tiny portions of food- little and often. Porridge (cooled) with non-acidic fruit (like pears or banana) is good, as well as mash potatoes and green veggies (leafy but not fermenty like brocolli). Keep everything plain & swig gaviscon advance beforehand.

@alhissss @Illumina70 @SadiqKhan I would always get the tube to central London by the way, but I'm talking about connections for the exterior boroughs. I would love to be able to cycle from Hammersmith to Earlsfield for example to see my best friend but the main road through Putney are horrific.

@alhissss @Illumina70 @SadiqKhan Would also back phasing out diesal and petrol cars in favour of electric. But it needs to be affordable. Eg my sister's girlfriend is a painter & wants a sustainable business but can't get an electric van due to the upfront costs.

@chimenesuleyman It's because media works in such a reactive way. I write a lot of nuanced pitches that get ignored because they're not trendy enough or won't get clicks. Hot takes aren't enough for the industry- we need to dismantle the way we tackle racism & misogyny which isn't happening.

@chimenesuleyman Yeah I just think she's become a scapegoat for three bigger issues- sensationalised clickbait, young women being encouraged to sell their personal stories to succeed and institutionalised racism.

@chimenesuleyman Media editors are also responsible for turning the tragic death of a white woman into a bigger story than others. That's also on them not Patsy. She's now getting so much abuse & I feel like she's been set up.

@chimenesuleyman She did but it's also a big deal for a student to be published in a mainstream paper, I can see why she wouldn't turn down the opportunity. The tone is poor but she's also young and trying her best. It shouldn't have been published- I just think the editors hung her out to dry.

@chimenesuleyman The article is in very poor taste but I think the blame should lie with commissioning editors rather than her. The click bait headline (not written by her) was always going to cause offence. She seems like a naive student who doesn't have a good understanding of media.
